definitions.definition: used to say that something is possible

examples.text: That may or may not be true.
He may have *(= perhaps he has)* missed his train.
There is a range of programs on the market which may be described as design aids.

definitions.definition: used to ask for or give permission

examples.text: You may come in if you wish.

definitions.definition: used when admitting that something is true before introducing another point, argument, etc.

examples.text: They may be well-meaning, but they are wrong.

definitions.definition: used as a polite way of making a comment, asking a question, etc.

examples.text: You look lovely, if I may say so.
May I ask why you took that decision?
If I may just add one thing…

definitions.definition: used to express wishes and hopes

examples.text: Business has been thriving in the past year. **Long may it continue** to do so.

definitions.definition: used to say what the purpose of something is

examples.text: There is a need for more resources so that all children may have a decent education.
I know that he has tried hard; be that as it may, his work is just not good enough.

definitions.definition: used to say that something seems the best thing to do in the situation that you are in, although you may not really want to do it

examples.text: If no one else wants it, we might as well give it to him.

definitions.definition: used to say that there is no real difference between two things that you might do

examples.text: If you are going to have sugar, you may as well have a bar of chocolate.
